predicate.note: Frames file for 'come' based on survey of initial sentences from big corpus and comparison with 'go'

example.name: destination
example.text: Mrs. Yeargin came to work on weekends.

example.name: with purpose
example.text: Students, teachers, and parents came to testify on her behalf.

example.name: destination as by-phrase
example.text: You may come by the agency to read but not copy the books.
example.arg: to read but not copy the books

example.name: come back (not phrasal)
example.text: They aren't going to come back to the US.

example.name: come after
example.text: Portfolio managers come after the highest rates.

example.name: arise in
example.text: Part of the charm comes in recognizing one's self in the novel.
example.arg: in recognizing one's self in the novel

example.name: arise from
example.text: It comes from a single acre of grapes.
example.arg: from a signle acre of grapes

example.name: arise of
example.text: Ringers are filled with the solemn intoxication that *trace* comes of intricate ritual faultlessly performed.

example.name: come_back (arise again)
example.text: They aren't going to come back on the US market.

roleset.name: become
roleset.note: see also 'come to terms', come_about below

example.name: come true
example.text: Its forecasts didn't come true.

example.name: come of age
example.text: The attack commercial has come of age in an off-election year.

example.name: non-specific price
example.text: Chateau Yquem now comes dear.

example.name: come to terms (not phrasal)
example.text: Tokyo comes to terms with its new status

example.name: just object
example.text: Steeper prices have come about because supplies are low.

example.name: I cannot imagine why
example.text: Buick came in fourth among US cars.

roleset.name: turn on

example.name: unaccusative
example.text: The lights came on this morning.

roleset.note: Let's just hope the other sense of "come on" doesn't appear in WSJ

example.name: unaccusative
example.text: Scoring High first came out in 1979.

roleset.name: become publically gay

example.name: generic idiomatic
example.text: John came out of the closet last week.

example.name: with audience
example.text: John came out to his family last week.

roleset.note: To my ear, at least, these two usages cannot overlap: *John came out of the closet to his family (last week).

role.descr: thing devised, brought forth, come up with

example.name: Transitive
example.text: Sellers are in a race *trace* to come up with the priciest bottle.
